description: From Middle English wid, wyd, from Old English wīd (“wide, vast, broad, long; distant, far”), from Proto-Germanic *wīdaz, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁weydʰh₁- (“to separate, divide”), a dissimilated univerbation from *dwi- (“apart, asunder, in two”) +‎ *dʰeh₁- (“to do, put, place”).

Cognate with Scots wyd, wid (“of great extent; vast”), West Frisian wiid (“broad; wide”), Dutch wijd (“wide; large; broad”), German weit (“far; wide; broad”), Danish vid (“wide”), Swedish vid (“wide”), Icelandic víður (“wide”), Latin dīvidō (“separate, sunder”), Latin vītō (“avoid, shun”). Related to widow.

entries.meaning: Having a large physical extent from side to side.
examples: We walked down a wide corridor.
The inquiry had a wide remit.

entries.meaning: (sports) Operating at the side of the playing area.
examples: That team needs a decent wide player.

entries.meaning: On one side or the other of the mark; too far sideways from the mark, the wicket, the batsman, etc.
examples: Too bad! That was a great passing-shot, but it's wide.

entries.meaning: (phonetics, dated) Made, as a vowel, with a less tense, and more open and relaxed, condition of the organs in the mouth.
(Scotland, Northern England, now rare) Vast, great in extent, extensive.
(obsolete) Located some distance away; distant, far. [15th–19th c.]
examples: the contrary [being] so wide from the truth of Scripture and the attributes of God

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Far from truth, propriety, necessity, etc.
(computing) Of or supporting a greater range of text characters than can fit into the traditional 8-bit representation.
examples: a wide character; a wide stream

entries.meaning: away from or to one side of a given goal
examples: The arrow fell wide of the mark.
A few shots were fired but they all went wide.

entries.meaning: So as to leave or have a great space between the sides; so as to form a large opening.
(cricket) A ball that passes so far from the batsman that the umpire deems it unplayable; the arm signal used by an umpire to signal a wide; the extra run added to the batting side's score
